etymology.description: 鬼(鬼) (guǐ, "ghost") + holding stick or tiger claw -> depiction of fear
etymology.interpretation: The character 畏(wèi, "fear") visually represents a ghost holding a stick or a combination of a ghost's head and tiger attributes, symbolizing something threatening that induces fear.

examples.chinese: 面对危险(面對危險)，他不畏艰险(他不畏艱險)。
examples.pinyin: Miàn duì wēixiǎn, tā bù wèi jiānxiǎn.
examples.english: Facing danger, he is not afraid of hardships.

examples.chinese: 他畏权(他畏權)，不敢发声(不敢發聲)。
examples.pinyin: Tā wèi quán, bù gǎn fāshēng.
examples.english: He is intimidated by authority and dares not speak up.

examples.chinese: 有的人因为自身弱小(有的人因為自身弱小)，对强者总是存有畏惧(對強者總是存有畏懼)。
examples.pinyin: Yǒu de rén yīnwèi zìshēn ruòxiǎo, duì qiángzhě zǒng shì cún yǒu wèi.
examples.english: Some people, because of their own weakness, are always intimidated by the powerful.
